text: there are two developments today from
the world climate conference protestors
appeared in large numbers for the first
time on the streets of copenhagen about
250 of them found out from the center of
the city apparently headed for some
pre-arranged targets Danish police were
out in force to meet them by midday 50
people had been arrested meanwhile in
Brussels the European Union pledged 3
billion dollars to a fun designed to
help poor nations cope with climate
change earlier I talked to the times as
Tom Zeller about both developments so
Tom what were these protests really like
how big are they how significant do you
think they were too on Friday they were
significant in that they were the first
substantial protests since the talks
began on Monday and people have been
expecting that there would be protesting
or wondering when when they were going
to start so this was this was the first
one but as protests go I would
characterize it is fairly small maybe
two to three hundred protesters all told
and and the police were pretty effective
in shutting them down the protesters had
a plan to fan out across the city and
target and perhaps vandalize or disrupt
businesses at several large
international corporations now there was
actually an other development today in
that the European Union has agreed to
give three billion dollars to the fund
to help smaller and poorer countries
manage climate change how is significant
is this development it's hard to say how
significant it will be it's not exactly
finalized but it does represent a first
step one of the biggest sticking points
in the negotiations so far has been
financing for for climate mitigation and
adaptation for poor countries
particularly island countries who are
likely to bear the brunt of climate
change so they've they've made of show
this week of saying that they're not
ready to move on in the negotiations
until they get clear and very real
commitments for substantial financing
from industrialized countries okay Tom
thank you so much for your time my
pleasure
you
